dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?

Hey, I'm doing okay, I guess. Just been thinking about how overwhelming everything feels with trying to finish my degree and dealing with all this personal stuff. It's been a lot to handle, and I'm just really ready for it to be over.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a detailed account of their life stressors, providing insights into their emotional state, personal history, and current challenges. Empathy and rapport have been established, with a comprehensive understanding of the client's situation. This meets the goals of the exploring phase, suggesting readiness to move towards guiding to strengthen motivation for change.

dialogue_total.statement: That sounds like a lot to juggle right now. What would it mean for you to finish your degree and navigate through these personal challenges?

Finishing my degree would feel like a huge weight lifted off my shoulders. It’s like this chapter of constant stress and struggle could finally close, and I could start focusing on rebuilding and moving forward in my life.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire to finish their degree as a means to alleviate stress and move forward. There's evidence of Change Talk with a focus on relief and future rebuilding. However, the discussion has not yet fully explored actionable steps or addressed confidence levels, and ambivalence may still be present.

dialogue_total.statement: Completing your degree seems like a big step toward relief and new beginnings. What parts of your life do you imagine improving once you can start focusing on rebuilding and moving forward?

client: I think once I finish, I’d have more mental space to work on my marriage and maybe find a job that I enjoy. Hopefully, I can also start rebuilding my life on my own terms without all the family drama hanging over me.

statement.reasoning: The client is showing signs of readiness to transition to the Choosing phase. There is clear Change Talk present, emphasizing the desire to finish the degree for relief and personal growth. The client has envisioned life improvements, such as focusing on their marriage and career. Despite the challenges, this indicates a strong motivation for change.

dialogue_total.statement: Imagining a future with more mental space and freedom to focus on your marriage and career sounds invigorating. Considering these priorities, what steps do you think you could take now to start moving toward these goals, even amidst the current pressures? Options might include setting small milestones for your degree, or seeking ways to reduce family stress.

client: I think breaking things down into smaller tasks could definitely help make finishing my degree feel less overwhelming. Maybe setting some boundaries with my family could also help me focus better on school and my personal life without getting sucked into the drama.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal to finish their degree and has discussed action steps like breaking tasks down and setting boundaries with family. Barriers have been identified, and the client is taking responsibility for managing them. The client appears committed to change and shows confidence in moving forward with rebuilding their life.

dialogue_total.statement: Breaking tasks into smaller, more manageable steps can certainly make them feel less daunting. Setting boundaries is a powerful way to protect your focus and energy, allowing you to prioritize both your education and personal life. You're showing a lot of insight by recognizing these strategies. As you move forward, maybe start by identifying those specific small tasks for your degree and thinking about what boundaries might be most helpful with your family. Remember, progress, no matter how small, is still progress. It's inspiring to see your determination and readiness to take these steps. Keep leaning on your strengths and self-awareness. I'm here to support you, and we can touch base on how things are progressing next time.

Thanks for the encouragement. I'll definitely try to figure out those first steps and see how it goes. I appreciate having someone to talk it through with, and I'll keep you posted on how things are going.

statement.reasoning: The client has discussed goals, coping strategies, and next steps regarding academics and personal life, with closure shown in their readiness to take action. The conversation naturally concludes with mutual understanding and support for a future check-in.

concern:
title: Life stressors, grades and finishing- Long post.
I just feel the need to share this as it feels cathartic to release this into the internet void. I have had the absolute worst life circumstances thrown my way while trying to complete and pass my classes for my degree. I started school in Fall 2021 with an accelerated program to finish in a year. Previously to starting school, my parents, who were married for 33 years, abruptly and sadly ended their marriage. My dad, who was in my life sort of consistently, completely abandoned, and left our family never to talk to us again. He married another woman who was horrific and edged us out of his life. My mom, who was extremely dependent on my dad, lost everything including her money. She was always sort of absent but it became much worse and devastating to witness and put a lot of pressure on me to help her out. Especially when COVID hit, that added a lot more pressure in general. I don't say this lightly but it absolutely devastated me. I had terrible depression, OCD and awful anxiety, but nonetheless I started my program hoping to push that aside. Another thing to note, is that I came from a very religious background and through connecting the dots realized that it was actually a cult that my dad started and funded mid way through the semester. I realized how much control and manipulation both my parents had put me through my whole life. It was overwhelming to say the least. My brain sort of broke around mid terms and I was crying through every single test. I, of course failed those exams, because I was so devastated and hurt, shocked and in deep grief. I was taking shots of tequila in the AM to calm myself down before my classes and mid terms to try to work through the pain, but it was to no avail. To avoid failing my classes, I took a leave of absence and didn't take my finals. At the same time, I was let go of my part time job which was helping support me with living expenses during my time in school. Lastly, my marriage was really strained and felt like it was also falling apart. The amount of stress and grief was overwhelming, and I was in a such a low place that I checked myself into an IOP (intensive out patient) therapy center. So for the first part of 2022, I went to over 400 hours of therapy to heal myself and deal with the intense trauma of it all. I lived off of credit cards and money I had saved for myself to pay for my program. As the year progressed, I was able to come above water for the first time and start getting back into my program. I had to take every final and write all of my research papers almost a year later, while also completing the current fall semester. It was so difficult to recall the information, but I was able to scrape by and finish with not stellar grades but still passed. I also enrolled back into the fall semester of 2022 and am finishing up my program (hopefully) this spring. Unfortunately my grades were sub par my first semester that I may be below the graduation requirement (3.0) , but I am hoping that my program will allow me to still walk and just pass me so I can move on from this life. I had to take out loans to live while I am in school because it is so involved, I cut ties with my parents (I was really close with my mom so that hurt), and am grinding out this semester to finally fucking finish! This isn't a post about pushing through adversity or anything, it is just venting that, this whole experience has been so hard and I am ready to be done. Lastly, being in your 30's in school is EXTREMELY harder than when I was in my young 20's.
